questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is the most potent vasoconstrictor?
questions.explanation: The most potent vasoconstrictor is urotensin2 followed by endothelin and angiotensin.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is a component of  granules of platelets?
questions.explanation: Epinephrine is a component of  granules of platelets. The different components of platelet granules are: •  granules • Fibrinogen • Fibronectin • PF4 • Factor V, VIII • PDGF • TGF •  granules • ADP • Calcium • Serotonin • Histamine • Epinephrine

questions.explanation:
Rees and Ecker's solution is used as a diluting fluid in the RBC pipette for performing platelet 
counts. Its composition is: The steps involved in platelet count are: I - Filling the pipette • Diluting fluid is drawn to mark 1 of the RBC pipette and expelled 419 
Sold by @itachibot • Blood is aspirated to 0.5 mark of the RBCs diluting pipette • Diluting fluid is aspirated to 101 mark • Blood and diluting fluid are mixed mechanically for 5 min II - Filling the counting chamber • Allow the counting chamber to stand for 20-30 minutes to allow the platelets to settle. • To prevent drying out of the preparation, it should be kept in a moist atmosphere, this is most 
easily arranged by placing the filled counting chamber in the bottom of a clean Petri dish, 
alongside which arrange a small piece of cotton wool which has been soaked in water and 
squeezed out. Petri dish lid is additionally put over the dish. • After 20-30minutes, the counting chamber can be removed and carefully transferred to the 
microscope stage. III - Counting the number of platelets • Focus on the surface of the hemocytometer chamber with a high power dry objective. Dim the 
light to make the thrombocytes visible, and count all of the thrombocytes in the entire center 1 
mm² (erythrocyte counting area) of both sides of the hemocytometer. This gives the number of 
thrombocytes in 0.2 l of 1: 200 dilution of blood. • The number of thrombocytes counted X 1000 = number of thrombocytes/l of undiluted blood. Components

questions.question:
Question 4: A 12-year-old girl with dengue hemorrhagic fever is being monitored by measuring platelet 
count. Spontaneous bleeding is associated with platelet values below  
 /µL.
questions.explanation:
Spontaneous bleeding (non-traumatic) is associated with platelet values below 20,000 
platelets/µL. It most often involves small vessels. The common sites for such hemorrhages are: • Skin • Mucosa of gastrointestinal and genitourinary tracts • Intracranial bleeding - most feared site of bleeding The production of the platelets is regulated by the hormone thrombopoietin produced in the 
liver. The platelet synthesis is also specifically increased by interleukin 6. The average lifespan of 
the platelets is 7–10 days. The normal platelet count is 1,50,000 - 4,00,000 /µL. 420 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following statements is true regarding functional platelet disorders?

options.a: Normal platelet count and normal bleeding time
options.b: Normal platelet count and increased bleeding time
options.c: Decreased platelet count and increased bleeding time
options.d: Decreased platelet count and decreased bleeding time

questions.explanation: Functional platelet disorders have normal platelet count and increased bleeding time. Classification of platelet functional disorders: • Defect in platelet-vessel wall interaction (disorders of adhesion) • Von Willebrand disease - deficiency or defect in plasma vWF • Bernard–Soulier syndrome - deficiency or defect in GP Ib IX • Defects in platelet-platelet interaction (disorders of aggregation) • Congenital afibrinogenemia - deficiency of plasma fibrinogen • Glanzmann thrombasthenia - deficiency or defect in GPIIb-IIIa • Disorders of platelet secretion and signal transduction • Storage pool deficiency - -Granule deficiency and gamma-Granule deficiency • Quebec platelet disorder • Chediak–Higashi syndrome • Gray platelet syndrome • Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome • Disorders of platelet coagulation-protein interaction • Scott syndrome - defect in factor Va-Xa interaction on platelets

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following statements is false about vonWillebrand factor?

options.b: Its deficiency can also cause factor VIII defect
options.c: Its deficiency may cause defective platelet adhesion
options.d: It serves as a carrier for factor VIII

questions.explanation:
Von Willebrand factor (vWF) is not synthesized by hepatocytes. They are produced by endothelial 
cells of liver and megakaryocytes. It is also found in: • Platelet granules - lesser compared to endothelial cells • Endothelial cells within cytoplasmic vesicles called Weibel-Palade bodies • Subendothelium - binds to collagen It mediates the adhesion of platelets to sites of vascular injury (subendothelium). It links the 
exposed collagen to platelets. It facilitates platelet to platelet interaction and also stabilizes the 
hemostatic plug against shear forces. It is a carrier protein for factor VIII and also protects it from proteolytic degradation 
and stabilizes it. The half-life of factor VIII is about 2.4 hours when free and 12 hours when bound 
to vWF in the circulation. Since vWF stabilizes factor VIII, a deficiency of vWF gives rise to a secondary decrease in factor 
VIII levels. This may be reflected by a prolongation of the partial thromboplastin time (PTT) in 
von Willebrand disease types 1 and 3. 421 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: A 24-year-old woman is found to have uncontrolled bleeding after a minor cut injury. Her lab 
investigations are given below. Which of the following statements are false about her 
condition?

options.c: Type 3 is inherited as autosomal dominant

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of von Willebrand disease (vWD). Type 3 vWD is 
inherited as an autosomal recessive disease. The characteristics of different subtypes of vWD are: Type 1 is the most common subtype of vWD. In Type 2, vWF is expressed in normal amounts, but 
missense mutations are present that lead to defective multimer assembly. This type has several 
subtypes, of which type 2A is the most common. Laboratory findings in vWD: • Prolonged bleeding time • Normal platelet count • Hess test - positive tourniquet test due to defective platelet adhesion • Ristocetin-induced aggregation - defective and diagnostic of this disease • Platelet aggregation with ADP, collagen, and thrombin - normal • Increased aPTT Though the synthesis of factor VIII remains normal, the half-life of VIII in plasma decreases due 
to reduced vWF (carrier) levels. This leads to secondary VIIIC deficiency in plasma. So, the 
intrinsic pathway of coagulation is affected. Hence, aPTT is increased in these patients. Description

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following occurs due to a defect in  granules of the platelets?
questions.explanation:
Hermansky–Pudlak syndrome occurs due to a defect in platelet  granules. Platelet granules disorders include: • Gray platelet syndrome - involves  granules and characterized by thrombocytopenia with large 
platelets that appear pale on the peripheral smear (due to deficiency of the  granules) • Quebec platelet syndrome - defect in  granules • Hermansky–Pudlak syndrome - defect in  granules and characterized by hypopigmentation and 
bleeding manifestation • Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome - mutations in the WASp gene expressed in the X chromosome and 
characterized by microthrombocytopenia, eczema, recurrent infections

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following statements is false about Bernard-Soulier syndrome?

options.a: There is defective adhesion of platelets to sub-endothelial matrix
options.b: Deficiency of the platelet membrane glycoprotein complex Ib-IX is seen
options.c: Platelet aggregation by ristocetin is normal
options.d: It has an autosomal recessive inheritance

questions.explanation:
In Bernard–Soulier syndrome, platelet aggregation by ristocetin is abnormal. The receptor for vWF i.e. Ib-IX is essential for normal platelet adhesion to the subendothelial 
extracellular matrix. In this condition, there is deficiency of Gp Ib/ IX. Clinical manifestations 
include epistaxis, ecchymoses, menorrhagia, gingival bleeding, and gastrointestinal bleeding. Laboratory findings seen in Bernard-Soulier syndrome: • Prolonged bleeding time • Moderate thrombocytopenia • Platelet aggregation by ristocetin is deficient (but ADP, arachidonic acid, epinephrine, collagen - 
normal). • Clot retraction - normal • Abnormally large platelets The image given below shows the abnormally large platelets on peripheral smear seen in 
Bernard-Soulier syndrome. 424 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: A 4-year-old girl with a history of easy bruising was referred for further evaluation. Her 
previous lab reports showed that platelet count and morphology were normal. Platelet 
aggregations tests are given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Glanzmann thrombasthenia. It is an abnormality of platelet GPIIb-IIIa (fibrinogen receptor). Platelets are unable to adhere to 
each other and to the underlying tissue of the damaged blood vessels. It is inherited in 
an autosomal recessive manner. The symptoms include mucocutaneous bleeding in the neonatal 
period, menorrhagia, ecchymoses, epistaxis, and gingival hemorrhage. Types of Glanzmann thrombasthenia include: • Type 1: Absence of GPIIb-IIIa • Type 2: Reduced surface expression of GPIIb-IIIa/ Essentialis athrombia - clot retraction is 
normal 425 
Sold by @itachibot • Type 3: Dysfunction of GPIIb-IIIa Laboratory features of Glanzmann thrombasthenia: • Normal platelet count and morphology • Platelet aggregation occurs in response to ristocetin, but not to other agonists (such as ADP, 
thrombin, collagen or epinephrine) • Clot retraction is absent

questions.question:
Question 12: 413 
Sold by @itachibot A 1-year-old boy is brought with a history of recurrent impetigo. Physical examination 
findings are given below. Platelet counts are low and peripheral smear shows abnormally 
small-sized platelets. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome (WAS). The given image 
shows (A) multiple petechiae over face and hematoma under the right eye and (B) eczema of the 
foot. This syndrome is an X-linked recessive, primary immunodeficiency disorder involving the WAS 
gene. It is characterised by the triad of: • Severe eczema • Thrombocytopenia • Recurrent infections Small platelets are seen in: • Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome • X-linked thrombocytopenia Large platelets are seen in: • Bernard-Soulier syndrome • Myeloproliferative syndrome • Myelodysplastic syndrome • May–Hegglin anomaly • Gray platelet syndrome

questions.question:
Question 13: A 28-year-old woman presents with epistaxis, easy bruising and menorrhagia. There is no 
history of drug intake. Physical examination shows scattered petechiae and a normal-sized 
spleen. Her lab investigations are given below. Antibodies against which of the following can 
lead to this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). 
Autoantibodies seen in ITP are most often directed against platelet membrane glycoproteins 
IIb-IIIa or Ib-IX. It is a diagnosis of exclusion due to the following findings: • Bleeding tendency - petechiae • Low platelet count, elevated bleeding time • Presence of megathrombocytes in the peripheral smear - a sign of accelerated thrombopoiesis • Female preponderance 426 
Sold by @itachibot • Absence of splenomegaly Note: Prothrombin time (PT) is normal in ITP.

questions.question:
Question 14: Which class of antiplatelet antibodies are seen in patients with chronic immune 
thrombocytopenic purpura? 414 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Antiplatelet antibodies in chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) are mainly IgG class. Autoantibodies most often directed against platelet membrane glycoproteins are IIb-IIIa or Ib-IX. 
It can be demonstrated in the plasma and bound to the platelet surface in about 80% of patients.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 27-year-old woman is diagnosed to have idiopathic ITP. Which of the following features is 
least likely to be seen in her?
questions.explanation:
Lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly are uncommon in idiopathic (primary) ITP. They are seen in 
secondary ITP. Chronic ITP occurs most commonly in adult women younger than 40 years of age. The 
female-to-male ratio is 3: 1. It is a type II hypersensitivity reaction. It is of 2 types: • Primary or idiopathic - without any risk factors • Secondary - presence of predisposing conditions like SLE, HIV, CLL Signs of accelerated thrombopoiesis that are seen in this condition are: • Megakaryocytes in bone marrow • Megathrombocytes (abnormally large platelets) in peripheral blood The image given below shows 2 megakaryocytes seen in bone marrow aspirate (Wrights stain). Acute ITP is mainly a disease of childhood. It occurs with equal frequency in both sexes, mostly 
after a viral illness. It is self-limited condition, resolves within 6 months. 427 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 16: Patients with which of the following predisposing conditions are likely to develop chronic 
immune thrombocytopenic purpura?
questions.explanation:
Systemic lupus erythematosus, HIV infection, chronic lymphocytic leukemia, antiphospholipid 
antibody syndrome can predispose to the development of secondary immune thrombocytopenic 
purpura (ITP). The predisposing conditions of secondary chronic ITP include: • Autoimmune conditions • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APS) • Immune thyroid disease • Evans syndrome • Lymphoproliferative diseases • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia • Large granular T-lymphocyte lymphocytic leukemia • Chronic infection • Helicobacter pylori • Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) • Hepatitis C virus (HCV)

questions.question:
Question 18: 415 
Sold by @itachibot All of the following commonly cause drug-induced thrombocytopenia except
questions.explanation:
Terlipressin does not cause drug-induced thrombocytopenia. Drug-induced thrombocytopenia can be caused by: • Vancomycin • Quinine • Rifampin They cause thrombocytopenia through direct effects on platelets or secondary to immunologically 
mediated platelet destructions. Quinine, quinidine, and vancomycin bind to platelet glycoprotein 
and create antigenic determinants that are recognized by antibodies.

questions.question:
Question 19: A post-operative patient was started on prophylactic unfractionated heparin for DVT. Which 
of the following is false regarding this drug?

options.a: It is an indirect thrombin-factor Xa inhibitor
options.b: It is safe in patients with renal impairment
options.d: On development of HIT, LMWH can be started alternately

questions.explanation:
The risk of severe heparin-induced thrombocytopenia is lowered with LMWH but not eliminated. 
Hence, once severe HIT develops even LMWH exacerbates the thrombotic tendency and must be 
avoided. Management of HIT includes the immediate withdrawal of heparin therapy and instituting an 
alternative non-heparin anticoagulant.

questions.question: Question 20: Patients with which of the following conditions is associated with ADAMTS13 deficiency?
questions.explanation:
ADAMTS13 deficiency is associated with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). ADAMTS13 is also called vWF metalloprotease which degrades very high-molecular-weight 
multimers of von Willebrand factor (vWF). Its deficiency causes accumulation of these multimers 
in the plasma and promotes platelet activation and aggregation. TTP is a part of a spectrum of clinical syndromes called thrombotic microangiopathy. They are 
caused by insults that lead to excessive activation of platelets, which deposit as thrombi in small 
blood vessels. Features of TTP include: • Fever • Thrombocytopenia • Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia • Transient neurologic deficits • Renal failure 429 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 21: A 7-year-old girl is brought with complaints of hematuria and melena for 10 days. Laboratory 
investigations reveal mild thrombocytopenia and normal coagulation tests. Peripheral smear 
is given below. Which organism is most frequently involved in this condition? 416 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing helmet cells or schistocytes are 
suggestive of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). This condition is most commonly associated 
with enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli strain O157: H7 worldwide. This strain releases Shiga-like toxin. This toxin is absorbed from the inflamed gastrointestinal 
mucosa into the circulation and causes endothelial dysfunction. It leads to platelet activation and 
aggregation. Children and older adults are at the highest risk. The image given below shows schistocytes or helmet cells seen in HUS.

questions.question:
Question 22: Deficiency of which of the following complement components is not associated with atypical 
hemolytic uremic syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome is not associated with deficiency of CD59. It is associated with deficiency of the following components: • Complement factor H • Membrane cofactor protein (CD46) • Complement factor I These three proteins prevent excessive activation of the alternative complement pathway. Deficiencies of these proteins can be caused by inherited defects or acquired inhibitory 
autoantibodies. The disease may be associated with a remitting, relapsing course.

questions.question:
Question 23: Coombs test is found to be positive in a patient with thrombocytopenia. Which of the 
following conditions could be a likely cause?
questions.explanation:
430 
Sold by @itachibot Coombs test is positive in immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) as it is an immunogenic cause 
of thrombocytopenia. Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) and 
disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) are nonimmunogenic causes. Hence, Coombs test is 
negative in these conditions.

questions.question: Question 24: Which of the following is affected in patients with Weber-Osler-Rendu syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Weber–Osler–Rendu syndrome is a disorder of the blood vessels. It is an autosomal-dominant disorder caused by mutations that modulate TGF- signalling. It is 
also known as hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia. This condition is characterized by dilated, tortuous blood vessels with thin walls that bleed 
readily. Bleeding is most common in the mucous membranes of the nose (epistaxis), tongue, 
mouth, and eyes, and throughout the gastrointestinal tract. Platelet count, prothrombin time (PT), and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) are 
normal. Clinical conditions in which abnormalities of vessel wall cause bleeding include: • Infections - meningococcemia, infective endocarditis, rickettsioses • Collagen defects - Ehlers–Danlos syndrome, scurvy, and Cushing's syndrome • Perivascular amyloidosis - most common with amyloid light-chain (AL) amyloidosis • Henoch–Schönlein purpura • Drug reactions 431 
Sold by @itachibot Coagulation Pathway Disorders
